entry.title: Currency Changeover needs on productive SAP S/4 HANA On-Prem and Private Cloud Environment
entry.content:
Introduction

This blog outlines the typical business triggers that drive the need for a currency changeover in a productive SAP S/4HANA environment. It also highlights the possible realization methodology to support such transformations.

General Business Triggers

Currency conversion requirements are usually driven by strategic, regulatory, or compliance-related events that necessitate a change in the currency model of your SAP system. These scenarios often arise during financial transformations, mergers, organizational restructurings, or statutory reporting changes. Common business triggers include:

  • Legal Currency Change in a Country: A country may mandate a change in its local currency due to reasons such as joining a monetary union (e.g., adoption of the Euro), experiencing hyperinflation, or undergoing political or economic reform.
  • Extension of Reporting Currency: The current ERP system may be configured for only one local reporting currency. Due to requirements such as hyperinflation, currency instability, or IFRS reporting, businesses may need to enable an additional parallel local currency in their productive environment.
  • Group Currency Alignment for Global Operations: Companies operating across multiple countries under different subsidiaries may need to establish a unified group reporting currency to align financial reporting across application modules.
  • Change in Corporate Headquarters/ Group Structure/ Merger & Acquisition: A shift in the corporate headquarters or the inclusion of a new entity with a different group currency may require changes to the existing group currency setup for consolidated financial reporting.
  • Parallel Valuation of Inventories in different valuation methods: Organizations may need to enable transfer pricing and support parallel inventory valuations to gain financial insights from different valuation perspectives and meet reporting requirements.

Possible Scenarios of Currency Changeovers in SAP S/4HANA System

Currency changeover requirements in an SAP S/4HANA system can arise in various business scenarios depending on the reporting, legal, or strategic needs. Below are some common scenarios with illustrative examples:

Scenario 1: Change of First Local Currency Across All Company Codes

A requirement to change the primary local currency (currency type 10) consistently in a company code using a fixed exchange rate.

  • Example: Company code 1000 is currently using INR as the first local currency. The requirement is to change it to USD.

Scenario 2: Introduction of a Parallel Currency with Valuation View

Business requires an additional parallel currency integrated across FI and ML, associated with a specific valuation view (e.g., 11, 12, 31, or 32) to support group or profit center valuation.

  • Example: For company code 1000, there is a need to introduce Group Currency in Group Valuation as a parallel valuation view.

Scenario 3: Introduction of a Freely Definable Currency

The need to add a freely definable currency within the FI application module to support additional parallel reporting.

Refer to SAP Note 2334583 – Introduction of new currencies / currency types in SAP S/4HANA, which describes how to manage new currencies via the Manage Currencies Cockpit.

  • Example: For company code 1000, the requirement is to introduce a freely defined currency for additional reporting.

Scenario 4: Changeover of Group Currency (Client Currency)

Changing the Group Currency (currency type 30) across the system consistently—for example, from EUR to USD. This may involve replacement across all application modules, such as FI, CO, and ML, where group currency is already in use.

  • Example: For company code 1000, the group currency needs to be changed from USD to EUR.

Scenario 5: Introduction of Group Currency in Systems Without Prior Usage

In systems where Group Currency was not used historically—such as ECC systems using CO currency types 10/20—the migration to S/4HANA may result in the CO currency (now known as "Global Currency" - Refer SAP note 2344012 - Currencies in Universal Journal) occupying the KSL field group in the ACDOCA table. Introducing group currency in such a case requires consistent integration across all modules, including FI and CO, and overwriting existing KSL values where necessary.

  • Example: For company code 1000, the requirement is to introduce Group Currency as both the Controlling Area Currency and an FI-integrated currency (BSEG level).

Scenario 6: Organizational restructure (change Controlling area currency)

Organizational Restructuring such as a merging multiple controlling areas into a single, unified structure to support centralized management may require the alignment of controlling area currencies to ensure consistency across the organizational hierarchy.

Example: There are 3 Controlling Areas 1000, 2000, 3000 with varying currency settings. Requirement is to merge the controlling areas 1000 and 2000 into 3000.

 Scenario 7: Activation of Universal Parallel Accounting (UPA):
To comply with multiple accounting standards, organizations may seek to activate Universal Parallel Accounting, which requires alignment of existing currency configurations and pre-requisites.

Example: For company code 1000, 0L and 1L ledger is active with company code currency (LC1) and group currency (LC2) and a freely defined currency. Requirement is to activate business function UPA and align the currencies and ledger across application module -FI, FI-AA and ML.

Realization Methodology

Once a company code is productive or live with transactional data, changing the configured currency must not be performed by simply transporting the modified configuration. Moving configuration changes without transforming the already posted documents can lead to data inconsistencies in the live system, potentially causing critical disruptions in business processes—such as clearing open invoices.

To make changes in currency settings, both the configuration and the associated transactional data must be transformed. For transforming existing posted documents, the SAP DMLT Currency Conversion Service is required. For more information, refer to the Currency Conversion Solution Brief.

Such data transformations in a live production system demand a highly precise and controlled changeover, ensuring consistency at the database level and seamless continuity of SAP software operations. Therefore, every relevant business scenario should be carefully reviewed in the system, considering current configurations and customizations across all connected application modules.

SAP DMLT offers a technical feasibility study to outline system data dependencies and prerequisite conditions. This is followed by a detailed customer workshop. The realization of the transformation requirement is delivered under a separate professional consulting contract and executed as a project.

The overall delivery process is broadly divided into two parts:

1. Pre-Qualification of Requirement

It is essential to pre-qualify the business requirement to ensure the right-fit transformation solution is offered. This starts with gathering preliminary details about the business requirement and application usage within the system through a technical questionnaire, available at Data Unification & Harmonization.

Based on the responses, SAP can propose a feasibility study to assess the system, evaluate overall complexity, and deliver a detailed proposal. This assessment typically takes around two weeks, including the deployment of analysis tools in the system.

An SAP solution expert will perform the system assessment and present the key insights during a customer workshop session. This is followed by the provision of commercial details through the regional SAP Market Unit.

2. Project Delivery

Depending on the complexity of the engagement, the required number of mock execution cycles will be determined during the scoping phase. In general, data transformation projects of this nature involve a minimum of three mock cycles before the production data cutover. The purpose of a mock execution is to simulate the complete production data conversion, validate the results, and estimate the overall downtime required for the production system. Each mock execution cycle includes several phases, which can be broadly classified as follows:

2.1 Technical Preparation Phase of Add-On (Uptime):

These types of transformation capabilities are deployed into the customer system as a separate add-on, delivered as transportable content. The mock execution system should be a recent copy of the production system, with hardware configuration closely matching that of the production environment. Once the tool content is deployed, the technical preparation phase begins, during which SAP DMLT experts prepare the transformation tool. This phase typically takes 2–3 weeks and includes uptime activities and the generation of technical programs for the relevant table-fields.

2.2 Data Conversion Phase (Downtime):

After the uptime preparatory activities are completed, the agreed business downtime begins. During this period, currency conversion is performed directly at the database table-field level. All relevant currency values (currency key/amount) are updated in the respective parallel currency fields in affected application areas (e.g., FI-GL, FI-AA, ML, CO etc) using a fixed exchange rate. Such conversions are applied retroactively for all fiscal years and Go-Live is not bound by a key date.

2.3 Post-Conversion Data Reconciliation Phase (Downtime):

Currency conversion may result in rounding differences, especially in accounting areas where specific rules apply—such as clearings that must net to zero. It is generally recommended to ignore rounding differences from previous fiscal years and reconcile only the current fiscal year. For business continuity, reconciliation of current fiscal year data is performed immediately after the conversion to mitigate the impact of rounding differences and to synchronize data across tightly integrated modules such as FI, CO, and ML.

2.4 Post-Processing Testing Phase (Downtime):

Once the reconciliation phase is complete, the transformed system is handed over to the customer’s IT/application team for a sanity check during downtime. Upon successful completion of the sanity check, the transformed system is reopened for normal business operations.

How to Engage with SAP

If your business requirement involves transforming any currency-related aspect in a live, productive SAP S/4HANA system, you should engage with the SAP Data Management and Landscape Transformation (DMLT) consulting team.

There are two primary ways to initiate the engagement:

  1. Create a Support Incident
    Submit an incident via the SAP ONE Support Launchpad under the component:
    CA-LT-SRV (Landscape Transformation Services)
  2. Contact via Email
    Reach out directly to the DMLT Global Consulting Experts by emailing-  sap_dmlt_gce@sap.com

The SAP DMLT team will guide you through the pre-assessment process, feasibility evaluation, and project-based service engagement tailored to your specific system and transformation needs.

Reference SAP OSS Notes:

3476589 - Parallel Currency Transformations in S/4HANA

481938 - System Landscape Optimization Services

3229024 - S/4HANA Local Currency Changeover - Central Note

3334743 - S/4HANA / SFIN 720/730: Is a subsequent implementation and activation of a Profit Center Valuation and/or Group valuation possible?

2882025 - Multiple valuation approaches/transfer prices in SAP S/4HANA, on-premise edition

175758 - Deactivating transfer prices/multiple valuation approaches

Other References:

Blog Post: DMLT- Currency Conversion Services Overview and Insights

Currencies Managed in Parallel in the Universal Journal | SAP Help Portal

Disclaimer: This blog is intended only for knowledge sharing about currency conversion service on SAP S/4 HANA which might help customer in their landscape transformation requirements. It should not be considered as guideline for performing such transformation services on their own in the SAP landscape. Any data transformation efforts should be thoroughly assessed in consultation with qualified subject matter experts, supported by a comprehensive system study, and aligned with the appropriate approvals from your auditors.

entry.title: Amazon Seller Central SAP S4 HANA integration Part 2 - Fulfilled by Merchant
entry.content:
Banner Image - SAP S4 HANA and Amazon FBM Integration Explained.

Just incase you landed on this directly, this is a second chapter of how you can integrate SAP S4 with Amazon Seller Central if you are operating under Fulfilled by Merchant model. In the first part - How to get started with SAP S4 HANA and Amazon Seller Central integration,  I discussed how I started building SAP Integration with Amazon Seller Central. The challenges and difficulties in getting and maintaining Amazon developer ID. We also talked about various Amazon API structure and various Amazon merchant models.

Understanding Amazon FBM process using SAP S4 SAP Sales and Distribution (SD) cycle

In this post, we are going to be talking about how you can integrate Amazon in case of Fulfilled by Merchant (FBM) scenario. I assume that most of the audience here would be well versed in SAP Sales and Distribution. If you are too, FBM is a drop ship kind of arrangement with Amazon, where customers come and place an order on Amazon, the shipping happens from Merchant’s warehouse.

What is Amazon FBM Model

Amazon then settles account with Merchant on a periodic basis. If you are with me so far, you got the important gist of the process. Let me show you how you can integrate FBM process using standard SAP SD cycle.

Let us break the integration into individual components.

  • Merchandize and catalog sync
  • Inventory synchronization
  • Amazon Order syncing with SAP
  • Out going delivery and tracking number
  • Invoice generation and A/R Posting
  • Return and refunds
  • Financial reconciliation between SAP and Amazon

A. Syncing merchandise with Amazon Seller Central Account

You may be selling only a part of your offerings on Amazon. Making a neat store with a proper tree structure and products assigned to them is of course the first step in getting started.

This is often done manually. Product information is enriched with proper images, description, related items for cross sell, specifications and more. See below Apple's store on Amazon with categories neatly laid out. 

Apple's Amazon Store with Categories and Sub-Categories

A key link to SAP’s material master and Amazon’s listing is the ASIN number. There are several ways to maintain ASIN numbers within SAP.

  • Text with Material
  • Custom table
  • Customer Material Info records
  • Unused field in Material Master

Customer material info records is the the cleanest way to do so. This is so because to be able to run SD cycle, Amazon has to be created as a business partner within SAP.

Maintaining Material Information in Customer Material Info Records with ASIN Numbers

 

It must be noted that the listings must be accurate and any orders placed for an item you have discontinued and are not being able to fulfill is dealt ruthlessly by Amazon. This reflects into your ratings and also search rankings.

B. Inventory Synchronization

You have to let Amazon know how much of each ASIN you have in stock ( ATP quantity). This becomes so crucial that it can make or break your Amazon store.

Syncing ATP Quantities with Amazon is a must for FBM Merchants.

As I mention that any orders placed on Amazon, if unfulfilled by merchant brings you down several notches and gives your closest competitor to rank above you.

Remember that SAP is your system of records. All B2B, EDI, Direct to Consumer orders being fulfilled centrally from the application. Each B2B order can change ATP across SKUs considerably.

So in essence, there are only two ways to deal with this situation.

  • Highly efficient integration which updates the inventory quantities several times a day.
  • Creating a separate plant or storage location exclusively for Amazon orders.

Another dimension to inventory sync is multi location stock.

If your inventory is spread across multiple warehouses in different regions, it’s best to sync these stock levels to Amazon. Amazon uses its intelligence then to calculate the estimated delivery time when customer sees the product. Receiving the product in 6 days versus 2, could be the single deciding factor for him to place order to browse other merchants.

 

C. Syncing Amazon FBM orders into SAP S4

The single most important aspect of this sync for all merchants is getting Amazon FBM Orders into their ERP, as efficiently as possible. This helps them get a window to be able to pick pack and ship the goods from the respective warehouse and let Amazon know the shipping details. 

In my experience working with several Amazon customers, a successful and optimized Amazon order in SAP should have the following key elements.

  • Amazon Order Number - I use PO number field for the same.
  • Shipping address - This not only ensures accurate shipping but also correct tax calculation. Remember that Amazon collects the tax on your behalf and it should match SAP’s calculation.
  • Bill to - This will be always Amazon for you.
  • Amazon Fees and Charges - You should have each Amazon fees and charges at the line item as mapped conditions type. Remember that some condition type can be statistical. For example the tax Amazon collected. If you do this part correct, the net amount payable by Amazon will match what it shows on your Amazon merchant portal. This I would say is the litmus test for orders synced.

Amazon Fees and Charges must be mapped to Condition Types within orders for better concilliation

  • Product and Quantities - Each ASIN must be converted to respective material numbers.

Litmus Test for Amazon Order Synced with SAP is that Net Amount must match what it shows as Payable on Amazon Portal

D. Outgoing Delivery and Tracking details

Amazon orders being shipped out of warehouse are usually small parcels. When PGI is done for these orders, tracking number should be related back to Amazon. Amazon notifies the end customer about the shipping details.

Amazon expects high operational efficiency from the merchants, specially the ones under FBM model.

Shipping goods as early as possible is really important for FBM Merchants

Hence, orders must ideally be shipped the same day, or even better within few hours.

This again calls for efficient and bi-directional integration.

While merchants may ship the goods in a timely manner, they are responsible for a timely delivery too. Hence any carrier delay also affects them adversely.

While this may seem unfair, there is a solution which Amazon offers around this. Amazon Veeqo is Amazon’s new acquisition which helps FBM merchant reduce their shipping cost as well as de risk them from carrier delays. Hence if a FBM merchant use Veeqo, any carrier delay doesn’t affect their ratings.

Bill of Lading is a good placeholder for storing tracking number for Outgoing Deliveries

E. Invoice

Interestingly, vendor invoice is not something Amazon is interested in getting. However for completeness of the process, merchants need to post SD Invoice when then post accurate receivables.

F. Return and Refunds

Amazon’s customer service and return policies are exceptional. When a customer returns goods, merchants need to raise a RMA. When goods are received at their end, Amazon issues them a credit.

In this case, a return order must be created in SAP with an inbound delivery and Post Goods Return followed by credit memo. The amount must match the respective line item in the original order.

G. Payment reconciliation

Amazon usually has a 2 week settlement cycle. This is amount paid for 2 week of sales net of returns. Given the volume of transactions, it becomes difficult to do it manually. A payment reconciliation report like the one below ease this entire process.

Why your Amazon settlement looks different from A/R shown in SAP

Despite doing the above integration, you may still find some differences in the amount you expected versus what Amazon paid you. This is so because there are some non order related, account level charges that may have been applied.

Some of them include any promotional event that you may have run with Amazon. Amazon also keeps a margin, some sort of deposit for every merchant. This margin safeguards Amazon to fulfill its commitment to customers on case merchant goes out of business. The margin amount d fluctuates as business transaction grows and hence adjustment may be required.

A few manual Adjustments may be needed despite integration

The good thing is that this is not usual or monthly phenomenon. Also these can be adjusted with few manual postings.

Without integration this entire reconciliation becomes manual and tedious.

Frequently asked questions

Here are some frequently asked questions regarding FBM questions in general and its integration with SAP in particular.

1. What is FBM and how is it different from FBA?

FBM stands for Fulfilled by Merchant. In this model, you (the seller) are responsible for storing, packing, and shipping the products when a customer places an order on Amazon.
On the other hand, FBA (Fulfilled by Amazon) means Amazon takes care of storing and shipping your products from its own warehouses.

2. How does the integration process differ for FBM?

In FBM, since the seller handles fulfillment, the integration focuses on syncing orders, inventory, deliveries, tracking details, and payment reconciliation between Amazon and SAP. You’re also expected to respond quickly to new orders and keep inventory up to date to avoid penalties from Amazon.

3. Is the integration approach different between SAP S/4HANA and SAP ECC?

The core logic remains similar, but S/4HANA offers improved capabilities—like better data structures and more streamlined APIs—which can make the integration smoother. However, both require proper mapping of orders, products (ASINs), and financial data.

4. Can I consolidate Amazon orders into a single SAP order?

It’s not recommended. Each Amazon order should be created as a separate sales order in SAP. This ensures better tracking, accurate taxation, shipping, and proper return/refund processing.

5. Why is financial reconciliation so important?

Even after syncing all the order details, Amazon might deduct fees or hold a margin at the account level. Without regular reconciliation between Amazon reports and SAP receivables, these mismatches can cause accounting issues and missed revenue.

6. What is Amazon Veeqo and how can it help FBM sellers?

Veeqo is a shipping and inventory tool by Amazon, especially useful for FBM sellers. It helps reduce shipping costs and protects your account ratings from delays caused by third-party carriers. If the delay is on the courier side and you’re using Veeqo, Amazon won’t penalize you.

7. What is multi-location inventory and why is it important?

If you store inventory across different warehouses, syncing stock levels with Amazon helps customers see more accurate delivery timelines. For example, a buyer may prefer a seller who can deliver in 2 days versus 6. This improves chances of making a sale.

8. How do I link my SAP materials to Amazon listings?

You need to match each product’s ASIN (Amazon Standard Identification Number) with its corresponding Material Number in SAP. The cleanest way to do this is by using Customer Material Info Records in SAP, especially if Amazon is set up as a customer in your system.

9. How often should inventory be synced with Amazon?

Ideally, multiple times a day. Amazon expects real-time inventory updates to avoid overselling. If that's hard to manage, you could also dedicate a separate plant or storage location for Amazon orders to simplify tracking and syncing.

10. Do I need to send invoices to Amazon?

No, Amazon doesn’t ask for your invoices. But you still need to create and post invoices in SAP so your books are accurate and receivables are tracked properly.

11. What happens if I can’t fulfill an Amazon order?

Amazon is strict about fulfillment. If you fail to ship an order, your ratings and rankings take a hit—which can reduce your visibility and sales. That’s why tight integration and up-to-date inventory are critical.

12. How are returns and refunds handled in SAP?

When a customer returns a product, Amazon issues a credit. On your end, you should create a return order in SAP, do the Post Goods Receipt, and generate a credit memo—all while matching the original order details to keep records clean.

entry.title: Controlling and Scheduling the Production Using the Work Center Formula Parameter
entry.content:
Business Requirement

Company X wants to determine the duration or cost of operation required to produce a given product depending on factors like work center or tool.  

Company X uses a multiplier called the efficiency factor to the standard execution time, which varies depending on the age of the tools used or weather conditions, etc. They want to execute the process in their SAP Cloud ERP. 

Solution at High Level 

This solution focuses on calculating the execution time of an operation based on the efficiency factor
defined during the creation/updation of production routing. The multiplier that Company X uses is created as a custom field (called YY1_EFF_FACTOR) in Production Routing.

Steps to follow:

1. Access the Custom Fields app from the SAP Fiori launchpad.

2. Choose Add Fields to create a custom field.

3. In the New Field popup, set the Business Context to Manufacturing: Bill of Operations  Operation (PP_BILLOFOPERATIONS_OPERATION)

4. Set the field type to Quantity with Unit, as no other Business context or field types are supported for Work Centre Formula Parameters.

5. Once the required data is entered, choose Create and Edit. 

6. On the  General Information tab, take note of the Field Component Name ending with the suffix ‘_PPO’. This suffix is used to map the custom field to a parameter. 

7. On the User Interfaces tab, enable the custom field’s usage for the relevant SAP GUI screens, CDS Views, and Services. 

8. Enable the custom field’s usage for the relevant business scenario. Enable Routing to Production Order on Operation Level for Discrete Manufacturing.

9. Navigate back to Custom Field work list page.

10. Search for EFF_FACTOR. Select EFF_FACTOR for business context Manufacturing: Order Operation (PP_ORDER_OPERATION).

11. On the User Interfaces tab, enable the custom field’s usage for the relevant SAP GUI screens, CDS Views, and Services.

12. Create a workcenter formula parameter ZPP in the Define Parameters activity (ID: 102242). In your configuration environment, use the search function to open the configuration activities. For more information, see also Configuration Environment of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 

13. Create the parameter with origin 8 (Custom Field from Operation). Fill in all the necessary data, leaving the ‘Field Name’ field blank. 

14. Once the parameter is created, create a WKC formula where the SAP standard parameter SAP_01 is multiplied by ZPP to calculate costs in the Define Formulas for Work Centers activity (ID: 102002). In your configuration environment, use the search function to open the configuration activities. 

15. Once the parameter is created and formula defined, map the newly created custom field to Workcenter formula parameter. Use the Mapping Custom Tasklist Operation Fields to Work Center Formula Parameters configuration activity (ID: 106627) to map the fields. In your configuration environment, use the search function to open the configuration activities.

16. Therefore, the creation of the work center formula parameter, definition of the formula, and mapping of the work center parameter to the routing operation custom field are complete.
The next step will be to either create a new work center according to the business scenario or update the existing work center with the newly created work center formula.

17. In the work center, use the newly created work center formula parameter under capacities, scheduling, and costing as per the business need. 

Capacity:

Scheduling:

Costing:

18. For production routing, you can add new operations or update the same operation with a new work center having the newly created work center formula.

Change shown for routing operation 0060:

19. In the custom fields, EFF_FACTOR is visible, and we can enter some efficiency factor into it.

20. Create Production Order for same material.

21. Navigate to Operation Overview.

22. Note the set-up duration.

23. Come back to Routing and change EFF_FACTOR to 20.

24. Schedule the created PO for the same operation. You will notice a change in setup duration due to a change in EFF_FACTOR in the routing.

25. Similarly, in Production Order, change the EFF_FACTOR to 30.

26. Before rescheduling, note the set-up duration.

After reschedule, the duration changes based on the change in EFF_FACTOR.

By following these steps, Company X can effectively streamline its production processes, ensuring efficiency and cost-effectiveness. Embracing SAP Cloud ERP not only enhances operational accuracy but also empowers the company to adapt swiftly to changing conditions.

entry.title: Navigating the BP transaction Authorizations in S/4HANA : SAP Security Experts Guide
entry.content:
General Overview

The Business Partner (BP) transaction is the central tool for managing customer and vendor master data in SAP S/4HANA. For many customers, this represents a transition from older transactions like XK01, FK01, and FD01. This change is part of the core data model redesign in S/4HANA, aimed at consolidating customer and vendor information into a single, unified repository. By doing so, it eliminates data redundancy and streamlines business processes. This approach is often also referred to as Customer-Vendor Integration (CVI).

This shift has many SAP Security consultants scratching their heads. The consolidated transaction called BP in S/4HANA combines functionality from over 60 legacy transactions into one powerful master transaction. While efficient, This simplification introduces a lot of complexity — particularly for security.

When you check the SU24 data for the BP transaction, you'll find it can include anywhere from 20 to 80 authorization objects. While this extensive list provides fine-grained control over access—which is great from a security standpoint—it can also be overwhelming. Assigning the BP transaction to a PFCG role often means suddenly facing the task of maintaining values for 30 or more authorization objects, which few enjoy dealing with.

Another challenge with the BP transaction is that, despite having a large number of authorization objects available to control access, many of these checks are inactive by default. As a result, the transaction appears to offer granular control, but in reality, it lacks many essential authorization checks—making it difficult to enforce precise access restrictions.

If your organization has a central team managing master data, you may not encounter some of the challenges mentioned earlier. However, in scenarios involving geographically distributed teams and decentralized master data management, maintaining effective authorizations for the BP transaction can become a significant issue.

Now that we’ve identified the challenges, let’s explore how to tackle them. In this blog, I’ll clarify and break down the key authorization objects you can use to manage BP authorizations more effectively.

What all transactions BP replaced

Lets start with the basics, the following transaction codes are no longer available as standalone transactions in the S/4HANA system. You can verify the updated list by checking the PRGN_CORR2 table using transaction SE16 in your system.

  • FD01, FD02, FD03, FD05, FD06, FD08
  • FK01, FK02, FK03, FK05, FK06, FK08
  • MAP1, MAP2, MAP3
  • MK01, MK02, MK03, MK05, MK06, MK12, MK18, MK19
  • V-03, V-04, V-05, V-06, V-07, V-08, V-09, V-11, V+21, V+22, V+23
  • VAP1, VAP2, VAP3
  • VD01, VD02, VD03, VD05, VD06
  • XD01, XD02, XD03, XD05, XD06, XD07
  • XK01, XK02, XK03, XK05, XK06, XK07

It’s important to note that while you may still assign these transactions to users, executing them in S/4HANA typically redirects the user to the BP transaction, often accompanied by an informational message at the bottom of the screen "Redirecting to transaction BP"

 

Managing the Authorizations for Business Partner transaction

Just like restricting any other transaction in SAP, restricting BP transactions comes down to the correct restrictions across various authorization objects. We will go through these one by one. Lets start then,

When you Execute the BP transaction you are shown this initial screen(see figure) where you can search for a Business Partner(Customer, Vendor etc) using various criterias.

  • ✅ As expected an initial S_TCODE - checks for start transaction code access happens here. Nothing complicated so far,

Once you select a Business Partner the details of the business partner id displayed(see figure), and a lot of authorization checks happens at this level, this is where things gets complicated as well. Lets look at these one by one :

  • ✅ B_BUPA_RLT Business Partner: BP Roles

This Authorization object controls what BP role a uses has, these BP Role (don't confuse these with PFCG roles) defines what functions a user can perform (ACTVT) and also controls the assignment blocks visible in the BP screen(RLTYP). For example:- If the user selects "Business Partner(Gen.)" Role from the dropdown, it allows editing of basic(general) data of the BP. But if the users switches to a different role "Customer" then some additional tabs will open up where data relevant to cutomers can be maintained.

Although, SAP Delivers some standard BP roles these can still be configured and created in SPRO img configuration by your functional team if need arises.

SPRO → Cross-Application Components → SAP Business Partner → Business Partner → Basic Settings → Business Partner Roles →Define BP Roles

Read more about this here - https://me.sap.com/notes/3416144

Next is,

  • ✅ B_BUPA_GRP Business Partner: Authorization Groups

With this authorization object, you define which business partners can be edited on the basis of the authorization groups. Now this authorization is optional and You therefore do not have to assign this authorization if there is no master data requiring special protection.

This groups restrictions require 3 things to work properly -

  1. SPRO configuration which can be done here : SPRO → Cross-Application Components → SAP Business Partner → Business Partner → Basic Settings →Authorization Management -> Maintain Authorization Groups
  2. The group needs to be maintained in master data , this can be done via opening the Business partner in general role, Navigate to the Control tab of the BP screen, then maintaining the Authorization Group here. (see screenshot below)
  3. Include authorization object in the role assinged to the user with restrictions. Read more about this here - https://me.sap.com/notes/3416153

Next,

Based on whether you have opened Customer or Vendor different set of authorization will be checked.

  • For Customer - F_KNA1* authorization objects will be checked.
  • For Vendors - F_LFA1* authorization objects will be checked.

✅ F_KNA1_GEN/ F_LFA1_GEN - This authorization object controls which activities are permitted for the general data. The general data consists of the fields that are independent of the company code and the sales organization. This only has single authorization field for ACTVT

 
✅ F_KNA1_GRP/ F_LFA1_GRP - You use this authorization object to specify which activities are permitted for the individual account groups. The object consists of the "Activity" and "Account Group" fields. Note that this groups is different from the group in - B_BUPA_GRP.
 

 ✅ F_KNA1_APP/ F_LFA1_APP - You use this authorization object to determine which activities are allowed for customer/Vendor master records. The object is defined with the fields "Activity" and "Application authorization".

For all of these F_* authorization objects, You will get suggestion and pressing "F1" on the authorization objects will give you some help. These authorizations objects are well known adn documented.

Other Important Authorization objects

Apart from the major objects mentioned above, some of the other important objects are mentioned below. Most of these can be configured at location - SPRO → Cross-Application Components → SAP Business Partner → Business Partner → Basic Settings → Authorization Management

 

  • ✅ B_BUPA_ATT - This authorization object is optional and is typically used to restrict users to entering only specific values for certain fields. For Example: Suppose a user should only be allowed to create Business Partners with the country set to India. In this case, you can use this authorization object to ensure the user can only enter "IN" in the country field. Any attempt to use a different country code would be blocked based on this restriction. You can read more about this configuration here: https://me.sap.com/notes/3416118/E
  • ✅ B_BUPA_FDG = Authorization object B_BUPA_FDG on BP is used exclusively for field level customization. The user can enforce authorization on the fields in the BP screen. The user for example can set a particular field on the screen as display only even in the change mode for the business partner. You can read more about this configuration here: https://me.sap.com/notes/3416138/E
  • ✅ B_CCARD = You can use this object to regulate authorization for display and/or maintenance of payment card master data.
  • ✅ B_CCSEC = Use this authorization object to define who can display unmasked credit card numbers and who can evaluate or delete the access logs.
 
Some other authorization objects which control the Sales area and Company code level details of Business Partners are - V_KNA1_VKO, M_LFM1_EKO, F_KNA1_BUK, F_LFA1_BUK etc.

 

Miscelleneous

If you are still struggling with restricting access properly for BP transaction, You may find some of the below helpful :

✳️Create role with just 1 transaction - BP in it. Infact you can have multiple versions of such roles with various degree of access to the single BP transaction. These roles then can be incorporated into Composite roles for better administration. Your roles will look something like this:

  • ZBP_VENDOR - BP role with access to only Vendor(Supplier) Master Data
  • ZBP_CUSTOMER - BP role with access to only Customer Master Data
  • ZBP_MASTERDATA_ALL - BP role with Full access to both Customers & Vendors
  • ZBP_DISPLAY_ALL - BP role with Display all access

You can follow this helpful guide for role creation - Business Partner Authorization Tips and Tricks

✳️In SU24, you can set the check indicator for unused authorization objects linked to the BP transaction to "No". For rarely used authorization objects, setting them to "Yes, Inactive Default" helps keep things tidy. This simple step significantly reduces clutter and simplifies role maintenance.

✳️When troubleshooting, start by checking the user buffer using transaction SU56. If the user has multiple single roles assigned, they might be receiving access to the relevant authorization object from one of these roles—effectively bypassing the intended restrictions on the BP transaction.

✳️Ensure that the authorization object is included in the user's profile—this is especially important for optional objects like B_BUPA_FDG, which can be used to restrict access to specific fields within the BP transaction. If this object is not included in the user's role, or if it exists in an inactive state. The system will ignore the restrictions, and the user will have unrestricted access to the field. The system only enforces restrictions if the object is present and active in the user master record.

✳️Although rare, there are cases where the SAP system may not behave as expected or fail to respect certain authorization checks—potentially due to a system issue on SAP’s end. We encountered such a scenario where the system was incorrectly checking for activity "05" (Block) on F_LFA1_GRP objects even when simply displaying a Business Partner. SAP acknowledged the issue and provided a correction through an OSS Notes. https://me.sap.com/notes/3097438/E , https://me.sap.com/notes/3093933/E

✳️For handling complex scenarios or implementing custom logic, you can collaborate with your functional and development teams to explore available BADIs or customer exits that may be leveraged. Refer to the resources below to explore such solutions in more detail:

  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NKlshC0uyyE
  • https://me.sap.com/notes/0002606686
  • https://me.sap.com/notes/2309153

entry.title: Display Changes to Objects
entry.content:
This is a new analytical application in Business Event Logging. It lets you review the recorded field changes for an object.

Screen Areas

Information filter

You can use the information filter at the top of the screen to select which data is displayed in the chart and table. This allows you to view recorded field changes for objects in various ways. You must enter the Object and Time Interval, as they are mandatory filters. Additionally, you can use other filters, such as "Object Component" and "Changed By", among others.

Fig. 2: Filter bar

Visual filter

Visual filter provides a graphical interface for interacting with and filtering your data. It allows you to view and filter the frequency of Changes to Fields based on "Change Type", "Year and Calendar Week" as well as by "Object Component" such as Item or Schedule Line.

Fig. 3: Visual filter bar

Bar chart

The bar chart offers a concise overview of the frequency of specific change fields. By selecting a bar, you can filter the entries in the table. Additionally, utilize the View By filter to explore different dimensional data. You also have the option to change the chart type from the default bar chart for other kinds of charts.

Fig. 4: Bar chart in Hybrid view

Fig. 5: Bar chart in Chart-only view

The "Hybrid view," also referred to as "Chart and Table View," is the default setting that displays both the chart and the table simultaneously. Additionally, you have the option to toggle between "Chart-only view" and "Table-only view" within the chart area.

Fig. 6: Toolbar in chart area

Table

The table located at the bottom of the screen provides additional details regarding the logged changes to objects, including Change Field, Change Type, Object IDs, Changed By, Old Value, and New Value. In the "Settings" button, you have the option to customize the displayed columns to include information such as Object Keys, Activity ID, Source of Data, and more. Additionally, you can utilize the "Group By" and "Sort by" features for the columns.

Fig. 7: Table in Table-only view

Upon clicking on column "Object IDs" you will be directed to the details page of the Fiori app "Display Business Events by Business Object".

Fig. 8: Details page of Display Business Events by Business Object

Upon clicking on each row in the "Change Type" column, you are directly directed to the event details page (Fiori app "Display Business Event Logs"),  or a dialog popover appears, displaying concise event information.

Fig. 9: Event Type and Versions in a Dialog

Upon selecting a table entry, you will be directed to the details page of the Fiori app "Display Business Event Logs".

Fig. 10: Details page of Display Business Event Logs
