entry.title: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Pro-tips for demonstrating SAP Fiori – Navigate with confidence
entry.content:
TL;DR – Tips and tricks for effectively demonstrating SAP Fiori as a functional consultant. Navigating confidently from app-to-app lets you focus on the business discussion around your demo. These tips are based on observing consultants in fit-to-standard workshops on an SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS02 system and working with them to improve their demo skills.

Here are some pro-tips based on real-life experiences for effectively demonstrating SAP Fiori in SAP S/4HANA, based on experiences with functional consultants. These suggestions can help you present SAP Fiori to your business users and provide suggestions for your change management team.  In this blog series you will find:

  • Researching your process (coming)
  • Organizing My Home
  • Navigating confidently – this blog post
  • Showing extension possibilities (coming)

Navigating confidently across a process helps you and your audience focus on the business process under discussion, instead of worrying about which button or link to click next. 

For example, below is a Shipping Specialist confidently navigating from creating outbound deliveries from sales orders (a bulk process that can be scheduled) to reviewing one of the newly-created outbound deliveries straight from the log.

Pro-tip: You can see there is no need to search for the next app - just use the provided links in front of you.

Navigating from Create Outbound Deliveries to reviewing the delivery created

In this blog post you learn how to navigate across apps and features easily, including:

  • Quick intro to SAP Fiori insight-to-action navigation
  • Start with your process diagram
  • Start your demo from the most relevant page
  • Explain app-to-app navigation basics - including SAP Fiori to SAP GUI for HTML
  • Move smoothly to the next logical task
  • Minimize data entry for fast navigation
  • Start from a page when moving to a new role
  • Cool stuff to show
  • Show new versions of apps

These tips are based on workshops at a recent customer project where consultants were demonstrating the latest SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS02 and higher.  All processes were demonstrated from the SAP Fiori launchpad. The consultants had a range of skills from very/somewhat familiar with SAP Fiori to brand new SAP Fiori.

For this customer, nearly 100 SAP Business Roles were activated and test users generated for each business role. For a handful of processes, 5 additional custom business roles were created.

Many of our consultants had 50 or more business roles assigned to their own user id. This created several challenges for consultants:

  • Hesitant or awkward navigation that distracted the audience and lost the consultant’s train of thought
  • Overuse of Search on Apps and Favorite Apps
  • Missing the obvious navigation link that all the audience can see in front of you

In this blog post you will find examples for a Fit-to-Standard workshop based on SAP Signavio Best Practices Scope Item 1IU Consignment Stock in release SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS02.

All examples in this blog post are taken from a SAP Cloud Appliance Library solution based on SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS03. To access a similar system, read SAP S/4HANA Fully-Activated Appliance: Create your SAP S/4HANA system in a fraction of the usual set...

 

Quick intro to SAP Fiori insight-to-action navigation

The idea behind insight-to-action is that when you see something that interests you, you can explore it further by navigating from app-to-app in an intuitive way.  For example, if you see an insight tile showing that there are 5 incomplete sales  documents, you can immediately drill-down to another app see which sales documents are affected and start taking some actions to get them to a better status.

Pro-tip: In demos, I usually refer to the insight-to-action behaviour as helping you follow your train of thought.

The term app includes wide range of launchpad content.  An app can be an SAP Fiori app, a classic UIs – such as a SAP GUI transactions, Web Dynpro applications, WebClient UIs – and any URL made available as a tile or link in the SAP Fiori launchpad.

Pro-tip: In demos, to explain how SAP Fiori launchpad can navigate across such a wide range of content, I use the phrase “The new world knows about the old world and can cater for it”.   Conversely, I would also say “the old world isn’t aware of the new world” to explain how staying in SAP Logon restricts you from accessing the new innovations available via SAP Fiori. Not a perfect analogy, as there are some minor exceptions, but it’s broadly true especially from a business user perspective.

There are many ways you can navigate between apps of the SAP Fiori launchpad. For example:

  • Select a tile, card or link 
  • Select a To-Do or a Notification
  • Launch apps using Search on Apps or App Finder
  • Navigate to related apps from Search on objects
  • Many apps provide additional navigation via action buttons, Related Apps buttons, Navigate To menus, list of links dialogs, process/document flow cards, and so on.

Insight-to-action helps you apply your job expertise efficiently.  It is NOT:

  • Telling you what decision you should make – although already in embedded AI use cases SAP Business AI will provide useful suggestions. For example, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, maintenance order recommendation
  • Stepping you through a process in a prescribed way – although, if you need a refresher on how to run a process, this is where SAP WalkMe can provide self-service tutorials.

Insight-to-action respects role boundaries via authorizations – you can only find and navigate to apps you are authorized to launch.  

Pro-tip: Similarly, within an app, you can only perform actions you are authorized to perform on data you are authorized to change. In demos, I use the phrase “Authorizations always wins!”.  More explanation on authorizations later in this post!

Hint: SAP WalkMe and SAP Joule are rapidly growing additional features to navigate beyond the SAP Fiori launchpad. For example, you may need to complete a process in another SAP Cloud solution, such as a Procure to Pay process that moves between SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP Ariba.

 

Start with your process diagram

In our project, our expert functional consultants typically started each Fit-to-Standard workshop by showing the relevant process diagram.  This was effective in helping the audience understand the process and to flush out any top-of-mind queries or concerns. 

Pro-tip: If your demo is based on a best practices process, you can use SAP Signavio Process Navigator to show the BPMN process diagrams. If not, you can use another tool such as SAP Signavio Process Manager to create them. In our workshops both tools were used, by uploading relevant process diagrams from SAP Signavio Process Navigator to SAP Signavio Process Manager. The consultant adjusted the process where needed in SAP Signavio Process Manager.

Within the process diagrams, you can see the SAP Business Role at the top and side of each swimlane. You can also select a task to find which business role performs this task. Make sure you point this out!

In a SAP Signavio Process Navigator process diagram, the SAP Business Role is shown at the top & side of the swimlane, and can be found by selecting any task.

Pro-tip: Starting with the business role is important for your audience to imagine how the process will work in practice in their enterprise. It gives you an opportunity to discuss “who does this in your enterprise right now?”.  This early discovery made it easier to capture business requirements and consider which stakeholders would be impacted.

Pro-tip: Explain that the SAP Business Role is a pre-defined fully functional template of launchpad content and related authorizations provided as a starting point for refining your own custom business roles. Custom business role design is typically done later in your project as part of UX Design.

 

Start your demo from the most relevant page 

Starting from a page of the relevant business role gives the audience an initial sense of the business role so they can imaging how this process fits into a user's day-to-day life.  Is it a major or minor process? Is the task performed every day or only periodically or triggered by a business situation? 

Pro-tip: At the start of a demo, before selecting the first app, take a moment to explain that spaces and pages navigation makes the on-system tasks expected of each business role largely self-explanatory.   You usually only need to do this once per workshop.

  • Simpler, focussed roles may have a single page – for example the Shipping Specialist. 
  • More complex roles – such as the Internal Sales Representative - may have multiple pages to split tasks for different processes, periodic activities, analytics, etc. Often there is an “Overview” page which is the first page of the space and used for everyday/multiple times per day activities that need to be accessed quickly.

For scope item 1IU Consignment Stock, the process starts with SAP Fiori app F1873 Manage Sales Orders which is in the Internal Sales space on the Overview page - the first page in the space.  In the example below, you can see the consultant briefly show the pages in the space menu, then select the first app Manage Sales Orders, then smoothly navigate to the next app - in this use case SAP GUI transaction VA01 - using the provided action button Create Sales Order - VA01. 

Select the space Internal Sales, show the pages of the space, select Manage Sales Orders, navigate smoothly to the next app

Pro-tip: If the page you need is not the first page in a space, make it a favorite page. This gives you a single click to get to the page and introduce or reinforce the business role that starts your process.

Pro-tip: Reassure your audience that with your custom business roles these page layouts can be very easily adjusted to suit how your enterprise wants people to work.  Page layouts are edited using the WYSIWYG editor in SAP Fiori app F4512 Manage Launchpad Pages.  Layouts can even be shared or merged for similar business roles.  Refer to Learning video: Creating SAP Fiori Launchpad Layouts for Custom Business Roles.

 

Explain app-to-app navigation basics

As shown in the example above, it’s very common for processes to start from an SAP Fiori app called “Manage <business object>”, for example "Manage Sales Orders". If it’s not the first app, most processes will use a Manage app somewhere in the process.  This provides the savvy consultant with an opportunity to make your audience comfortable with some basics of app-to-app navigation. Many Manage apps include navigations to other SAP Fiori apps and/or classic UIs, such as SAP GUI transactions and ABAP Web Dynpro applications. 

Hint: Naturally the more the use cases of a process are  covered by SAP Fiori apps, the less navigations to classic UIs (such as SAP GUI transactions) are needed.  SAP Fiori is focussed on innovations, so you should not expect SAP GUI transactions to disappear entirely.  

For the Customer Consignment Stock 1IU process in SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS02 the first step starts in SAP Fiori app F1873 Manage Sales Orders. You then select the action button Create Sales Order – VA01 to navigate to the classic SAP GUI transaction VA01 where you create a sales order .

Pro-tip: If your audience is used to using SAP GUI, the first time a SAP GUI transaction is an excellent opportunity to explain how SAP Fiori launchpad brings a unified experience across new SAP Fiori apps and classic Uis.

Common audience & consultant questions at this stage of the demo are:

  • Why do I need to go through an SAP Fiori app? Can’t I just go directly to the transaction code? After all that’s 3 extra clicks.
  • What’s this app? What does a Manage app do?

This is where you can show your skill as a demonstrator!

Yes, you can go directly to any app that’s provided as SAP Fiori launchpad content of your business role(s). For example, using favorite apps or the tile Create Sales Orders VA01 on the Internal Sales Overview page or Search on apps.

  1. For those coming from SAP ECC, you can show Search on Apps using the keyword VA01.
  2. For any audience, show Search on Apps using the keyword sales orders and show that all the apps I can use for Sales Orders can be found via the search results.

You see both of these keywords demonstrated below.

Using search on apps using keywords VA01 and Sales Orders

However using Search on Apps to find apps is often NOT the most efficient navigation option! 

A good demo should leave your audience with an understanding of the optimal approach.  You explain that in SAP Fiori a common way to find and act on business objects is through Manage apps.  Manage apps act as worklists where you can filter, sort, prioritize, what you need to do, and then launch to the relevant action(s). You can also navigate directly to related information, for example information you need to decide what action you should take.

Pro-tip: In demos I usually say "Think of Manage apps as the “one-stop shop” for that business object."

For example, in the SAP Fiori app F1873 Manage Sales Orders you can perform the following actions for Sales Orders:

  • Find sales orders by a wide range of criteria and sort/filter/group the list
  • Create – using VA01 or using the embedded SAP Fiori app F3893 Manage Sales Orders -  Version 2 
  • Create with Reference to a Contract or Quotation
  • Display a graphical view of the Sales Order status
  • Navigate to any other related Sales Order app (that you are authorized to use) from the hyperlink on Sales Orders
  • Navigate to any other related Customer app that you are authorized to use) for the Sold-To Party, Ship-To Party, or Payer
  • Export the list of sales orders to a spreadsheet or PDF
  • Perform bulk actions for multiple sales orders, such as Set/Remove Delivery Blocks
  • Expand a sales order row to display sales order details and to perform further actions on the selected sales order.

You can see some of these actions in the example below.

Showing a variety of actions in SAP Fiori app F1873 Manage Sales Orders

Pro-tip: How to explain manage apps to participants with a background in SAP ECC

  1. Explain that in ECC you would often have 3 or more separate transactions to Create, Change, and Display business objects. For example, VA01 to create sales orders, VA02 to change sales orders, VA03 to display sales orders. You might have more transaction codes to remember for additional actions to block/release/etc. This is a significant cognitive burden on business users!
  2. In practice, when using SAP ECC many people would maintain cheat sheets of transaction codes that they would consult to work out which app to use. Given that the transaction code is simply a technical id that has no business meaning, that’s a lot to remember!
  3. With SAP Fiori, as a business user you can find the technical id – for example using User Actions > About – but you don’t need to remember it. You can find any app by name or partial name in Search on Apps, App Finder, etc.

Hint: At this point you may be wondering why this process is using SAP Fiori app F1873 Manage Sales Orders and not F3893 Manage Sales Orders - Version 2. Scroll down to Show new versions of apps or TL;DR: Review the Feature Comparison for Creating, Changing, and Displaying Sales Orders

 

Move smoothly to the next logical task

When you are running tasks within the same business role, most of the time you want to move smoothly from one task to the next using the easiest available link or button in the current app.  Most apps provide several navigational options. These are supplemented by SAP Fiori launchpad features such as Search, To-Dos, and Notifications.

Pro-tip: The best navigation options pass the most amount of business context when moving from app-to-app. This avoids data re-entry which speeds up your process.  In order of most-to-least efficient, your best navigation options are:

  1. Action buttons are for primary actions – including Navigate To menu buttons, To-Dos, and Notifications
  2. List of links are for secondary actions and side questions - including Related Apps buttons
  3. Search on objects is for ad-hoc queries and interruptions 
  4. Search on Apps is a last resort – including favorite apps

 

Action buttons are for primary actions

These are usually the most obvious navigation option within an app.  They represent the primary actions expected from this app. They pass the current context to the target app. For example, values from the currently selected row(s).

If your app includes multiple rows and supports bulk actions, you may need to first select one or more rows on which the action is to be performed. This will be obvious.

For example, the action button Set Delivery Block is only available when at least one row is selected.

The bulk action Set Delivery becomes available when one or more Sales Order rows are selected

Pro-tip: The expand row icon “>” is a very common table action provided with many apps.  You don’t have to select the icon itself to expand the row.  It’s an indication that selecting anywhere in the whitespace on that row will expand it.

Expand icon ">" indicates that the row can be expanded to see more details

Action buttons usually appear at the top of an object page, i.e. an app that describes a single business object. For example, you can perform many actions from the Sales Order ( app Change Sales Order) .

Action button Create Delivery is in the header of object page Sales Order

Hint:  You should be aware that technically an action may be part of the same app, or a navigation to another app. As a business user you don’t need to know this.  As a consultant, you can use the SAP Fiori launchpad > User Actions menu > About to check which is the current app and the designated application component for SAP Support. This is useful if you need to find related SAP Notes or raise an SAP Incident for the app.

Special action buttons:

  • In some analytical apps action buttons can appear as Navigate To menu buttons. Like other action buttons they will pass the current context to the target app.
  • To-Dos and Notifications can be treated in the same way as action buttons, because they pass business context when used.

Pro-tip: What values gets passed depends on what's in the context of the source app, what the target app can accept, and what's been configured in the technical Launchpad App Descriptor Item (aka LADI or target mapping). This is where it can get quite technical!  If asked about this, then I usually explain that in general, quite a lot of information can be passed from/to a SAP Fiori app, but most SAP GUI transactions can only accept a very small number of fields and don't pass any fields to other apps. 

 

Know the impact of authorizations on Action buttons

Action buttons always respect authorizations.  You must be authorized to perform the action on the data.  This is true regardless of whether the button is visible or not, and whether the button is available or not.  For example, if you don’t have access to Set Billing Block on the selected sales orders you will get an error message when you press the button.  

Hint: Action buttons are not automatically hidden as the combination of actions and data authorizations can be complex, varying from user to user and from use case to use case.

Typical audience questions at this point are: Can we hide that button altogether from some users? Yes! This is where Clean Core extension techniques such as Adapt UI, App Variants, and Adaptation Projects can be useful. 

Pro-tip: Avoid getting into the details of what’s possible in Fit-to-Standard workshops.  Extension option discussions are usually too technical for a business audience. Capture the business requirement and the business reasons behind it.  Ultimately, which technique will be used and whether the change will be made at all will be discussed at later stages of your project.

 

List of Links are for secondary actions and side questions

Within SAP Fiori, you can assume every hyperlink navigates somewhere. 

Many apps include list of links dialogs on business object ids/names, and even on process/document flow cards. These links take you to related apps, i.e. apps related to the same business object. They pass the business object id directly to the target app.

Pro-tip: Set your favorite links to match your audience expectations.  You can use the links immediately from the initial list of links and from the Define Link List dialog (which is reached by More Links).  Promoting your favorite links in the Define Link List dialog saves you one click each time for the links you use again and again.

In our workshops, participants often asked about the sales order status and follow-on financial documents.   It was helpful to promote the links Display Document Flow - Sales Order  and Display Process Flow AR - Sales Document  to answer these queries. You can see promoting and using list of links in the example below.

Adjusting list of links to set your preferred links

Pro-tip: The first link of the list – i.e. the link on the object id – displays the business object itself.

Related Apps buttons are essentially the same as the list of links dialog. They will pass the current business object id to the target app. 

Pro-tip: Personally, I prefer using the list of links dialogs in demos because when you have a lot of apps in the Related Apps list it can be harder to spot your next app. However, there’s not much difference in speed. Compare these 2 examples of moving from the Outbound Delivery to My Outbound Delivery Monitor – which are both steps done by the Shipping Specialist.

This example uses the list of links on the Process Flow cards to move from the Outbound Delivery object page to My Outbound Delivery Monitor.

Using link lists from Process Flow cards

This next example uses Related Apps to move from the Outbound Delivery object page to My Outbound Delivery Monitor.

Using Related Apps to navigate from the object page to another app

 

Know the impact of authorizations on lists of links

Navigation links automatically respect your authorizations to launch apps.  For example, if there is a link provided on the sales order id:

  • If you have access to launch multiple sales order apps, you will see a list of links dialog with access to navigate to those sales order apps.
  • If you only have access to one other sales order app the link will take you straight to the other app.
  • If you only have access to the current app – and no other sales order apps – the sales order id will appear as a flat text without a link

 

Search on Objects is for ad-hoc queries and interruptions

The most overlooked option in the consultants running our workshops was the Search on Objects.  

From personal experience Search on Objects is a useful way to navigate when you have a query or interruption and need to jump back to find details on a business object id. 

It can be much quicker to find the business object id first, and then jump to the app you need, than the other way around - especially when you need to find ids based on partial ids or customer references.

With search on objects, you use fuzzy search wildcards to quickly filter and find the business object id.  Then you use search results to launch straight to the app you need.  Like List of Links and Related Apps, Search on Objects passes the current business object id to the target app.

You can see an example of using Search on Sales Orders for a partial Sales Order id in the screenshot below. Notice that the partial id is highlighted in the sales orders found in the search results. You can use the left-hand filter bar (funnel icon) to narrow down the search results if needed.  Expand the id you need to launch related apps passing the sales order id.

Search on objects using partial ids, names, or customers references with wildcards then launch the app you need from search results

 

Know the impact of authorizations on Search on Objects

There are more than 300 searches on business objects provided. Authorizations control which searches are available. Most consultants have far too many searches assigned! Reassure your audience that in real-life they would only see searches related to their business objects.   Like list of links and related apps, when you expand a search result only navigation links you are authorized to use will be shown.  

Pro-tip: The search result row header is a special navigation link to display object id itself.  For example, selecting  Standard Order 121 in the example above opens the Sales Order object page showing Sales Order 121.

 

Search on Apps & favorite apps are the last resort

Search on Apps will navigate to the app but does NOT pass any of the current business context. At best, you will have your Default Values applied when you launch the app from Search on Apps.  In an end-to-end process Search on Apps is the least effective option!

Pro-tip: Avoid Search on Apps when there’s any better navigation option available.

In one of our workshops, a consultant continually used Search on Apps even when there was a link in front of them that was obvious to all the participants.  For example, when transferring stock, a Material Document (aka goods movement) is created for you and a link is provided directly to the Material Document Id just created. Instead of taking the hint and selecting the link in front of them, out of habit they would go to Search on Apps, find the SAP Fiori app F1077 Material Documents Overview, and then use the filters to search for the document they just created.  That’s a lot of clicking around for no added value! By the end of the workshop, even the audience was pointing out the link! 

Pro-tip: When using Search on Apps, avoid entering the keyword manage! There are 100s of manage apps! When you are looking for a specific app it’s better to just enter the business object as the keyword e.g. “sales orders”. For example, for the roles assigned, there were 355 Manage apps, but only 38 apps related to Sales Orders.

Hint: Find out how search on apps is changing in future releases in SAP Fiori Transforming User Experience: SAP Fiori Launchpad adopts the latest SAP Design System

Pro-tip: When performing an end-to-end task for the same role, avoid returning to the SAP Fiori launchpad My Home between apps. Like Search on Apps, launching from a space/page or from favorite apps passes very little business context.  At best, Default Values will be applied when you launch the app from Search on Apps. 

Pro-tip: You may need to use Search on Apps or favorite apps when moving from SAP GUI transactions to a SAP Fiori app. While a small number of SAP GUI transactions are able to include links to other apps, this is rare.  You can also use the Back button ("<" icon) in the shell bar to return to the previous app. 

 

Minimize data entry for fast navigation

Before your demo:

  • Set your Default Values for frequently used fields
  • Create App Views for apps that you will visit multiple times

 

Set your Default Values 

Adjust settings for fields that you need to enter multiple times across the process, such as Display Currency, Company Code, Plant, purchasing org, sales org.

For example, in our workshops, consultants would typically set their default organizational fields such as Sales Org, Distribution Channel, and Division. 

You set your defaults in SAP Fiori launchpad > User Actions > Settings > Default Values as explained in the SAP Fiori launchpad User guide section Maintaining your Default User Values

For more on what's possible with Default Values, refer to:

  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Yes Key Users can set Default Values for other Users
  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Synchronizing Default Values with Set/Get Parameters

 

Create App Views and name them by use case

App Views save you time by setting filters, tables, and charts for your use case.  The more often you use an app the more time you save by having an App View.  You can create multiple app views for each app.  

Pro-tip: Create App Views for apps with filters, tables, or charts that suit your process use cases.  Name your App Views after your use cases so they are easy to find and select. If you are showing multiple processes or have several workshops planned, each consultant can create their own app views in advance or as part of the demo.

For the Customer Consignment Stock 1IU process, the SAP Fiori app F1595 Stock - Multiple Materials is shown at least 3 times to check how consignment stock and free stock is impacted by the consignment fill-up, goods issue, and returns are processed. It’s helpful to create an app view to focus the app on the consignment use case.

Below you can see an example of how we used an app view we created before the demo for SAP Fiori app F1595 Stock - Multiple Materials.  You can see how easy it is to create or update it using the Adapt Filters, table settings, and the app view actions Save as to create an app view or Save to update it.

Select an app view, adjust the view's filters with Adapt Filters and/or the view's table settings, then Save to update your view

Pro-tip: Explain that one or more public App Views for common use cases of an app can be created via Adapt UI by key users (i.e. expert business users). Public App Views can be shared to all users of the apps or restricted to users with nominated security roles.  Refer to SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Yes Key Users can create default app settings for filters, tables, and charts

Hint: One interesting question raised in our workshops was: Can public app views be maintained by someone other than the original author? For example, if the original author leaves the company.  We tested this and can confirm - Yes! - by using Adapt UI any key user who is authorized for Adapt UI for the app can maintain public app views.

 

Start from a page when moving to a new role

In our workshops some consultants would simply move from app to app without explaining that this task was done by a different role.  This frequently caused confusion for our audience who would start to ask “so who does that…?” questions.  

Pro-tip: Show your Process Diagram again whenever you are changing roles – or at least announce which role is runs the task. For example, when changing from the Internal Sales Representative to the Shipping Specialist. 

When you move to the Shipping Specialist role showing the Shipping space is a quick way to reinforce who is performing the next task

Announcing the business role also gives you an opportunity to discuss how they assign work “In our scenario this would be done by the Shipping Specialist… who does that work here?”  In our workshops, this question was useful to uncover special requirements around segregation of duties, device type needs, and other working conditions.  It can be very useful to capture the business context to inform the custom business role design in later stages. It also shows your audience you are interested in their unique enterprise perspective, which helps to build connection with your customer.

 

Cool stuff to show

SAP Business AI: If you have access, show SAP Joule – the generative AI assistant. Joule provides capabilities to perform some actions in a conversational dialog. This can save having to navigate to an app at all – or help you find the right app to use.

Collaboration via Microsoft Teams: in SAP Fiori apps using the Share button to share to email or share to Microsoft Teams chats, tabs, or cards.

Swap languages: Working with an international company? Discussing a process with a colleague in another country? No need to logoff - just change the language on-the-go in your SAP Fiori launchpad > User Action > Settings.  It's a quick way to encourage collaboration, break down language barriers, and simplify multi-country testing.

  • Pro-tip: From personal experience, make sure you know how the word English appears in your second language! I once changed the language from English to Thai and had to ask my audience which option to select to change back.

Show the context-sensitive help: When your audience are asking “What does this app do?” press the “?” Help icon in the shell bar. This takes you to the App Documentation of a SAP Fiori app via the button “What’s this app?”. For SAP GUI transactions, the help icon takes you to the SAP GUI transaction documentation.

  • Pro-tip: Context-sensitive help features for SAP S/4HANA are currently provided by SAP Enable Now and are expected to be provided by SAP WalkMe in future.

Handle error messages with ease: When you encounter an error/warning message, point out the error message area in the bottom left-hand corner of the screen. Expand the area and show the message long text, if available for your error messages.  Show how you can help resolve your own issues, including authorizations issues, through the self-service App Support.  From any app in the same user session, go to SAP Fiori launchpad > User Actions > App Support, review the log messages, and show downloading the logs to send them to your support team. 

  • Pro-tip: In our workshops we found App Support was a godsend in resolving technical issues quickly, by capturing all the relevant logs for the current user.

Never lose your work: Show an app with Draft capability such as F2499 Manage Customer Materials. If you get interrupted or change device your work is not lost even if the information is incomplete.  

Show keyboard navigation to improve entry speed by using the <TAB> key to move to forwards the next field and <SHIFT+TAB> to move backwards.

Resize the screen to show how the app will look on tablet or smart phone.

Convert a flat table to a hierarchical table: When you have an SAP Fiori app with a grid table (a table where you can adjust the column widths), use the table settings option Group By to create a hierarchical table.  For summable fields, your groups will show totals and subtotals. 

 

Show new versions of apps

When there are significant changes needed to an app, you may see a new app version released.  For example, F3893 Manage Sales Orders - Version 2 provides several benefits over F1873 Manage Sales Orders including:

  • Improved App View Personalization – filter and table settings are consolidated reducing view maintenance, more filter criteria and table columns are offered to cover a wider range of use cases
  • Embedded and streamlined Create/Change of Sales Orders – instead of having to navigate to transaction VA01. The streamlined creation includes simplified item creation, keyboard navigation, and copy/paste items from spreadsheet. During display/change, critical information is highlighted through embedded analytics. Refer to Journey of Managing Sales Orders in SAP Fiori – Item Details
  • Default Values applied when creating sales orders
  • Simplified bulk actions for setting and removing blocks on orders
  • Improved search functionality including free text search
  • More extensibility options – both Sales Order header and Sales Order Items support custom fields & data source extensions, Adapt UI for placing hidden and custom fields in all supported screens of the app
  • Intelligent Product Proposal when creating sales orders (optional)
  • Joule capabilities – use Joule to fetch sales order information or create sales orders with reference then navigate to the app to see more details

Pro-tip: Often when there are overlapping apps, you will find a Feature Comparison document highlighting the main differences. For example, SAP Help - Feature Comparison for Managing Sales Orders and Feature Comparison for Creating, Changing, and Displaying Sales Orders

In practice, we could have used SAP Fiori app F3893 Manage Sales Orders - Version 2 for many of the steps in this process. For example, for Consignment Fill-Up.  In our workshops we did encourage use of this new app and used where we could. 

Pro-tip: Showing a new app version encourages your audience to think about how the process can improve over time.  

In our workshops we adjusted the sales order type configuration as explained in the Feature Comparison documents so we could show how creating sales orders works in the new version of the app.

Creating a consignment fill up order using the Create Sales Order action of SAP FioriF3893 Manage Sales Orders Version 2

So why isn't F3893 Manage Sales Orders - Version 2 included in the Customer Consignment Stock 1IU test script already?

It comes down to the app lifecycle.  When an app needs to provide a complex mix of use cases, it can take several releases to complete the full roadmap.

SAP Fiori app F3893 Manage Sales Orders - Version 2 was first made available in SAP S/4HANA 2021 with a lot of care taken over the new design. 

Pro-tip: You can find some nice screenshots and demos in the SAP Fiori apps library - but always test it in your own sandbox as features have improved greatly since the original release. 

Available means can start to take advantage of these new features where they fit your use cases.  Where both the original version and new version of the app are available, you can use either app or both. You can even control which sales order types can be created using the new version to gradually take advantage of the new app. 

Find which use cases are covered in SAP Note 3138511 - Order Types missing in 'Manage Sales & - Version 2' apps

Pro-tip: Once the roadmap is complete, typically the older version will be marked as deprecated to inform all customers that it’s time to shift to the new version.

There was one feature we needed for scope item 1IU that is not supported in SAP S/4HANA 2023, which is the Output Preview to check what information has been sent to the Customer. 

  • In SAP S/4HANA 2023, you can check the Output Items to confirm that the output has been sent, but you cannot see the Output Preview from the new version of the SAP Fiori app yet.
  • In practice, this means you need to navigate to the app Display Sales Order SAP GUI transaction VA03 to access the Output Preview feature.  This is not difficult, but as a user experience, it’s a little awkward.
  • Happily, Output Preview was included in the 2502 release of SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, and we are expecting this feature will be made available in SAP S/4HANA 2025.

Hint: We had to tackle this question ourselves during our Fit-to-Standard workshops, where we had several different use cases for sales orders. Our customer was still deciding on their go-live release. They want to take advantage of innovations for this process where available.  In our workshops, we decided to use the new app where we could, and the older app only where we needed to, and to manage the queries from our audience who were already comfortable with the SAP GUI transaction VA01. 

 

Becoming a SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA guru

You’ll find much more on our  SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA topic page

Brought to you by the SAP S/4HANA RIG and Customer Care team.

entry.title: API Consumption - S/4 HANA Cloud,Public Edition and S/4 HANA Cloud,Private Edition
entry.content:
With the evolving SAP landscape and customers moving to S/4 HANA Cloud , our prime focus as a consultant is to follow a clean core approach.

SAP Business Accelerator Hub(https://api.sap.com/) is one such platform which helps us in discovering standard APIs,Events, Extensibility options

which we can consume in our S/4 HANA landscape to achieve end-to-end business functionality. This blog focusses mainly on the API consumption from

SAP Business Accelerator HUB and how it differs between the two of the S/4 HANA Cloud offerings - S/4 HANA Cloud,Public Edition and S/4 HANA Cloud,Private Edition.

We will first go through some of the basic differences and then focus on technically how we can use or consume these APIs in each of the environments.

 

S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition

S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition

Where to find?

 

Ready to use APIs available in Business Accelerator Hub(https://api.sap.com/) to be explored under the Tile -

 

Ready to use APIs available in Business Accelerator Hub(https://api.sap.com/) to be explored under the Tile –

 

Activation

 

Communication management based API Activation. APIs are part of a standard communication scenario. Communication scenario can be found from SAP Business Accelerator HUB as below –

 

 

SICF based API activation(OData V2)For OData V4 no specific activation is needed but the Service Group needs to be published. Not associated to any communication scenario.

 

 

Sandbox availability

“TryOut” option available in SAP Business Accelerator HUB for OData APIs to execute the CRUD methods with Sandbox data. Also you can deploy your own system to do tryout with your actual data of your S/4 HANA Cloud,Public Edition system.

 

 

 

No Tryout option available with any Sandbox. Also here the S/4 HANA system is in a private network and often there will be a Cloud Connector in between so TryOut options have been restricted for APIs for Private Edition

 

 


 

 

 

Consumption

API is consumed through a communication arrangement which is based on a standard communication scenario. Standard Fiori Application -   Communication Arrangements to be used for consumption.

For OData V2 API is activated through transaction code - /n/IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE.

For OData V4 API no separates activation is required but service group needs to be published through transaction code - /n/IWFND/V4_ADMIN

Practice Guide

We will be using OData V2 - API - API_PRODUCT_SRV as an example to demonstrate the activation of the API in S/4 HANA Public Cloud and S/4 HANA Private Cloud.

API Link for Public Edition – https://api.sap.com/api/API_PRODUCT_SRV/overview

API Link for Private Edition - https://api.sap.com/api/OP_API_PRODUCT_SRV_0001/overview

 

Scenario 1# Activating API in Public Cloud –

Navigate to the link https://api.sap.com/api/CE_PRODUCT_0002/overview  for the API or you can search the API as below.

In https://api.sap.com/ go to the tile SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition

 

Under APIs go to ODATA V2 and search with “Product” and open the one Product Master(A2X) which say ODATA V2 API and is “Active”  for usage.

 

From SAP Business Accelerator HUB you will get the SAP standard communication scenario for the API –

 

Here we will be creating arrangement for communication scenario – SAP_COM_009

Next create a communication user from the Fiori application “Create Communication User”.

 

Give a Username and you can use the “Propose Password” option or you can add your own password.

 

Next step is to create a communication system from the Fiori application “Communication Systems”

 

Click on “New” and provide a System ID and System Name –

 

 

Go to tab “Users for Inbound Communication” and assign the user you just created in the previous step using “Create Communication Users”.

 

 

For the ease of use you can check the checkbox “Inbound Only” which means you are not expecting any outbound communication (S/4HANA -> External) through this communication system and so you will not be asked to enter any user for Outbound communication user for this communication system.

Save the communication system.

Next step is to create the communication arrangement. Go to application “Communication Arrangements”

 

Click on “New”

In the following tab enter “SAP_COM_0009” as the standard communication scenario for API_PRODUCT_SRV.

 

Select the ‘Communication System'(from value help) which we have just created in the previous step. The assigned Communication User will now automatically appear in User Name field.

 

Click “Save” and it will activate your communication arrangement.

You can get your actual service URL for all Inbound Services associated, under the tab “Inbound Services” under the column “Service URL/Service Interface”.

Similarly all the Outbound services associated with this communication Scenario “SAP_COM_0009” will show under the tab “Outbound Services”.Outbound services are generally either SOAP Outbound services or IDOCs.

 

 

All the services that belong to the communication scenario “SAP_COM_0009” will be listed here under the tab “Inbound Service”.

Get the URL where the Service says “Product Master(A2X)” / OData V2”

 

The API link looks like this - https://<host>/sap/opu/odata/sap/API_PRODUCT_SRV

So this makes your API ready for consumption from the external system.

Get the service URL and test it from POSTMAN using the communication user that you created in the first step. In POSTMAN you can use it for Basic Authentication under Authorization.

You can call this URL from SAP Integration Suite using a OData V2 Adapter with basic authentication with the user you created in “Communication User” application.

Note – For Public cloud the way of activating a OData V2 service and OData V4 service are same unlike Private Cloud where there is a difference.

So for OData V4 the API will be also activated by a communication arrangement only as shown above and the URL will look like this - https://<host>/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_product/srvd_a2x/sap/product/0002/

Link to API Hub for the OData V4 API of Product Master - https://api.sap.com/api/CE_PRODUCT_0002/overview

 

Scenario 2# Activating API in Private Cloud –

First step same as Public cloud to find the API from https://api.sap.com/ .

Navigate to the link https://api.sap.com/api/OP_API_PRODUCT_SRV_0001/overview for the API or you can search the API as below.

In https://api.sap.com/ go to the tile SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition

 

Under APIs go to ODATA V2 and search with “Product master” and open the one Product Master(A2X) which say ODATA V2 API.

 

 

Next Run Transaction Code - /n/IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE

Click on “Add Service”

Provide System Alias = “LOCAL” and under Technical Service name – “API_PRODUCT_SRV” and click on “Get Services”

 

Then select the service you want to activate and click on “Add Selected Services”

You can provide the package where you want to assign the service.

 

If you want to use OAuth authentication you have to check the checkbox “Enable OAuth for Service”

The next step is to activate the service as shown below. However it is recommended to go and activate the service from SICF transaction code.

 

Your OData V2 Activation is complete and you can test it from the Gateway. You can call this service now from SAP Integration Suite with a technical user who has the necessary roles.

 

 

Bonus Scenario # Now we will see how we can activate a similar OData V4 service of Product Master.

To find the OData V4 API go to https://api.sap.com/ and go to the node – “SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition”

:291522iD133E2FCB72EF160:

 

Under APIs->ODATA V4 -> Search Product

 

Select the “Odata V4” one which is “Active” and not “DEPRECATED”

 

Under API Resources -> Attributes you will find the Service Group Name which you need to publish.

 

Now Go to Transaction - /n/IWFND/V4_ADMIN and click on “Publish Service Groups”

 

Next enter the Service Group Name you got from Business accelerator Hub and click on “Get Service Groups”

 

 

Now your OData V4 API will be ready for consumption from Integration Suite.

entry.title: Gaining Operational Insights with the SAP LogServ Workbook on Microsoft Sentinel - Part 4
entry.content:
Find your way to our central blog series entry here.

Dear community,

Following our previous deep-dives into LogServ usage with Microsoft Sentinel for SAP and customization, let's explore the operational insights available through Sentinel's built-in workbook for SAP LogServ monitoring.

Near real-time visibility atyYour fingertips

The SAP LogServ Insights Dashboard on Azure transforms raw log data into actionable intelligence. Navigate to Microsoft Sentinel > Workbooks > Templates and locate the pre-configured dashboard. 

 

Save to your workspace and open to get started. Make sure to select the Log Analytics workspace powering your Sentinel tenant first.

 

 

Key metrics that matter

The workbook provides comprehensive monitoring across four critical dimensions:

  • Total Events: Track log ingestion volumes (4M events shown)
  • Active Systems: Monitor connected hosts (36 active systems)
  • Data Freshness: Near real-time status indicators with color-coded alerts
  • Log Distribution: Understand log ingestion patterns across your SAP landscape components

The Log Volume Timeline reveals ingestion patterns, helping identify peak usage periods and potential anomalies. Notice how the 24-hour view shows consistent data flow with the characteristic SAP workload patterns.

Pay attention to the status legend: Fresh (green), Recent (orange), Older (red), and Stale (dark red). These indicators help SAP Security and SOC teams quickly assess data currency - critical for incident response.

The workbook automatically refreshes, ensuring your security operations center maintains current visibility into your SAP RISE environment's log ingestion health.

Proactive Alert Configuration

Transform workbook insights into actionable alerts using the Create Alert Rule button visible above the timeline. This creates Azure Monitor alerts directly from your LogServ metrics, enabling threshold-based notifications for critical scenarios like data ingestion anomalies or system connectivity issues. Configure alert rules to monitor total event volumes, data freshness status changes, or active system counts falling below expected baselines.

Azure Monitor's alert engine integrates seamlessly with action groups for email, SMS, Microsoft Teams, or webhook notifications to your operations team. For detailed configuration guidance, reference the Azure Monitor alerts documentation.

 

For those of you who prefer PowerBI for dashboarding...

See this Microsoft Learn article how to craft a dashboard from the Microsoft Sentinel queries for SAP LogServ.

 

Final Words

That’s a wrap🌯. You saw today how to observe log ingestion health and use data freshness indicators for your SAP LogServ solution in Microsoft Sentinel. The built-in views are easy to extend and customize for your own individual needs.

#Kudos to @Hemanth_Kusampudi and team for the partnership.

Get started with your deployment from here today.

What visuals are most helpful for your daily operations? Do you want special breakdowns for HANA database, and proxy components like the SAP WebDispatcher? Let us know in the comments or reach out directly.

Cheers Martin & Hemanth

entry.title: Key User Custom Fields: Maximum number of fields and characters
entry.content:
Key User Custom Fields: Maximum number of fields and characters

Have you ever wondered how many key user custom fields you could add to a specific business context? If so, this blog post is for you.

This blog post covers the following topics:

  • The maximum number of key user custom fields you can add
  • The maximum overall number of characters consumed by key user custom fields

Please note that for all S/4HANA editions, the actual numbers for the maximum fields and maximum overall number characters supported strongly depend on the S/4HANA release. In general, the maximum number of fields and the maximum overall number of characters consumed by key user custom fields have been significantly increased over time.

S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

In S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, you can figure out easily how much capacity for a given business context is left. This is directly shown while creating a new field using the Custom Fields app (see screenshot below).

Business Context Capacity

The field “Business Context Capacity” displays a percentage number telling you which percentage of the overall available capacity reserved for customers has already been consumed. When you hover over the “Business Context Capacity” bar, you see how many fields and how many bytes are available (see screenshot). As a rule of thumb, you can divide the number of bytes by factor 2 to get the free number of characters.

Also you can see the remaining capacity when you open the value help on the business context field of the “New Field” popup and then on the very right column you see the remaining capacity for the business contexts listed (see screenshot below).

Business Context Capacity shown in Business Context value help

Please note that for each business context, the responsible SAP application department defines the capacity available for customers individually. The only guard rail that exists is that the number of fields reserved for customers is never less than 100 fields and never less than 1000 characters.
If the available business context capacity is not sufficient for you, please create a request via the customer influence channel or create a customer ticket on the application component of the respective business context.

S/4HANA and S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition

In S/4HANA and S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, the business context capacity limits are not considered at all. You can add key user custom fields until you reach the technical limits given by ABAP dictionary. As soon as you reach these limits, you'll no longer be able to add additional key user custom fields. A popup will tell you that there is no more space left to create key user custom fields.

These limits are very high. For SAP_BASIS releases above 7.95, no customer has reached these limits yet.

The ABAP dictionary limits relevant in this context are:

  1. The maximum number of fields: the maximum number of fields supported in a database table. Note that for counting them, it's not relevant whether this field is a SAP standard field or not
  2. The maximum table width: this figure tells you how many bytes at max per table entry in a database table are supported. Note that for counting them, it's not relevant whether the bytes originate from a SAP standard field or not

Let’s have a look at these limits:

  1. Maximum Number of Fields
    • A database table can have up to 749 fields by default
    • Since SAP-BASIS release 7.73, the limit increases to:
      • 1,500 fields for application tables with a 'Column' storage type.
      • 1,000 fields for application tables with a 'Row' storage type
    • Since SAP-BASIS release 9.16, the limit has been further increased to:
      • 3000 fields for application tables with a 'Column' storage type
      • 1,000 fields for application tables with a 'Row' storage type (remained unchanged)
  2. Maximum Table Width
    • By default, the maximum width of a table is 4,030 characters
    • With the TABLEN feature activated (DDIC table DD02L, field TABLEN_FEATURE), the limit increases to 16,293 characters
    • Since SAP-BASIS release 7.95, the table width limit has been extended further to 256,000 characters

With this, we are done. I hope this blog helps you understand what the limits of key user custom fields are regarding number of fields and number of bytes.

Feedback, Comments, or Questions:

You’re cordially invited to provide them in the comments section below. Please follow my profile to get updates when I publish more posts on these topics.
Feel invited to post and answer questions here (https://answers.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26) and read other posts on the topic (https://blogs.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26/).

I want to thank Yasmina van Rooij (YasminavanRooij), Karsten Schaser (Karsten_Schaser) for their extremely helpful contributions.

Other related blog posts (just a small selection of the blogs available for custom field extensibility)

  • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/convert-manually-created-append-fields-to-real-key-user-custom-fields/ba-p/13967399
  • https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/key-user-custom-fields-in-s-4hana-cloud-private-edition-and-on-premise-dos/ba-p/14026871

entry.title: Commitments in focus: How SAP S/4HANA is changing the management of financial commitments
entry.content:
What does commitment mean in the SAP context? 

Commitments describe the outstanding financial obligations of a company. These include, for example, orders, provisions or approved but not yet utilized funds. Although no payment has yet been made, these items impact liquidity, budgeting and risk assessment. 

SAP records such obligations in the system in several modules, in particular in Materials Management (MM), Financial Accounting (FI) and Controlling (CO). It is precisely at this interface that SAP S/4HANA’s decisive advantage emerges. 

GRAPHIC 1: Schematic overview of commitment processing between MM, FI and CO 

From static reporting to real-time insight 

SAP ECC already offered the option of managing commitments. However, the flow of information was often sluggish, fragmented and poorly integrated. Analyses were based on upstream reports that rarely reflected the current data situation. 

SAP S/4HANA solves this problem with real-time data processing. Every relevant transaction, be it an order, an investment application or a provision, is immediately recorded in the system and can be analyzed instantly. The underlying SAP HANA database ensures that data is not only quickly available but also intelligently linked. 

Comparison of COOI and ACDOCA: the evolution of commitment management 

A key difference between SAP ECC and SAP S/4HANA lies in how financial obligations are managed and mapped. In SAP ECC, the COOI table (open orders, accruals and commitments) played a central role in commitment management. This table recorded open items and provided an overview of financial obligations but was often static and limited in terms of updates. 

With SAP S/4HANA, commitments are managed via the ACDOCA table. This central financial accounting table offers several advantages: 

  1. Real-time data processing:
    ACDOCA enables the recording and evaluation of transactions in real time. This means that every change is immediately reflected in the system, resulting in an up-to-date and accurate representation of financial obligations.      
  2. Integrated data structure:
    In contrast to the fragmented data management in ECC, ACDOCA integrates data from different modules and processes, providing a more comprehensive overview of financial obligations and their impact on the organization. 
  3. Extended analysis functions:
    With the ACDOCA data, organizations can perform complex analyses, such as plan/actual comparisons and trend analysis, which were previously difficult to carry out. This enables targeted management of the financial strategy and early identification of potential risks.     
  4. Flexibility and adaptability:
    ACDOCA's modern data structure supports easy adaptation to increasing requirements and the integration of new technologies such as AI-supported analyses and forecasts.     

This transition from COOI to ACDOCA clearly illustrates how SAP S/4HANA has advanced commitment management and supports companies in not only recording financial commitments, but also actively managing and strategically utilizing them. 

 GRAPHIC 2: Comparison of the commitment functionality in SAP ECC and SAP S/4HANA 

 

Advantages of real-time data processing in SAP S/4HANA: 

  1. Application example - supply chain management:
    A company uses SAP S/4HANA to monitor its stock levels in real time. By recording orders and deliveries immediately, it can react more quickly to changes in demand and avoid bottlenecks. This leads to more efficient warehousing and reduced storage costs.
  2. Case study - Financial planning:
    A company in the energy sector implements SAP S/4HANA to gain real-time insight into its financial obligations. By immediately recording investment requests and provisions, the company can plan its liquidity more accurately and identify financial risks at an early stage. This leads to improved strategic decision-making and optimized budget management.     
  3.  

A new level of integration and analysis 

Another milestone is the seamless integration. SAP S/4HANA not only links MM, FI and CO technically, but also creates a unified view of obligations. This means that not only individual items, but also comprehensive budget evaluations or plan-versus-actual comparisons are possible at the touch of a button. 

At the same time, modern analytics functions offer new insights. Companies can recognize trends, identify anomalies at an early stage and make decisions based on reliable figures. 

Explanation of the Fiori interface and its advantages: 

The SAP Fiori interface offers a modern, intuitive and responsive design that greatly simplifies access to SAP applications. Users benefit from a role-based user experience that takes their specific tasks and needs into account. This enables a personalized and efficient way of working, as users can quickly access the information and functions relevant to their role without having to navigate through complex menus and transactions. The Fiori interface is particularly beneficial for users without in-depth technical system knowledge, as it facilitates the use of SAP applications and increases productivity through clear visualizations and simple interactions.  

GRAPHIC 3: SAP Fiori dashboard with current commitment values 

 

Exposure in the project business: actively managing cash flow 

Commitments have a particularly strategic impact in the project environment. SAP S/4HANA makes it possible to update payment obligations assigned to WBS elements, networks and orders, automatically and with precise value types. This creates the basis for project-related liquidity planning based on actual obligations. 

Down payments, allocations and project-related target/actual comparisons can also be clearly mapped. The ability to adjust financial items as required also increases flexibility. 

GRAPHIC 4: Project-oriented commitment process from the WBS element to the commitment 

Concrete implementation and specific functions of SAP S/4HANA 

User-friendliness thanks to the Fiori interface  

A key difference in the implementation of commitment management between SAP ECC and SAP S/4HANA lies in the use of the modern Fiori interface, which enables more intuitive and user-friendly interaction. This interface supports a role-based and personalized user experience, allowing users to work efficiently without in-depth system knowledge. 

Use of intelligent functions for commitment management  

In addition, SAP S/4HANA offers specific functions such as AI-supported forecasting models that help to better manage future obligations and identify risks at an early stage. These models use historical data and probabilities to provide automated decision-making tools that significantly simplify commitment management. 

Technical implementation with CDS views and virtual data model 

In order to make optimum use of the functions and forecasting models mentioned, a robust database is required. The available CDS views in particular play a central role in analyzing the commitments. The content provides a manageable selection of CDS views that can be used to analyze the obligations. In the project context, it is advisable to check the associated virtual data model (VDM) and the definition of the key figures to see whether they reflect the requirements of the specialist area. This may result in expansion requirements that need to be mapped in the customer's own CDS views. In particular, when combining data from the two tables COOI and ACDOCA, it must be checked how these are merged. 

What's next? A look at the roadmap 

The development of SAP S/4HANA is far from complete. The upcoming releases promise, among other things, AI-supported forecasting models for commitment management. Automated decision-making aids based on historical data and probabilities will further reduce the burden on day-to-day business. 

A lot is also happening in terms of user-friendliness. The continuous improvement of the Fiori apps ensures that both controllers and project managers can work efficiently with commitments without in-depth system knowledge. 

Conclusion: Managing commitments, not just recording them 

Commitments not only show what a company has already incurred. They are a mirror of future expenditure and therefore an early warning system for the company's finances. SAP S/4HANA takes this tool to a new level by combining real-time data, integrated processes and dynamic analysis functions with modern implementation approaches and specific functions. With the Fiori interface and AI-supported forecasting models, commitments is transformed from a mere booking value into a strategic management tool. Companies that rely on these new possibilities can monitor commitments more specifically, manage budgets more precisely and identify financial risks earlier. The key to this lies in the intelligent use of existing data and a system that makes this data available in real time and in a user-friendly way. 

But that's just our view. How does your company perceive these changes? What experiences have you had with the implementation and use of SAP S/4HANA in commitment management? We look forward to hearing your perspectives and discussing new solutions together.

entry.title: Convert Key User Custom Fields to ABAP Managed Fields (AMF)
entry.content:
Introduction

Have you ever been in the situation that you created a key user custom field and then, when wanting to change the metadata of the field, the change turned out to be only supported by ABAP Managed Fields? 

If your answer is yes, then this blog post is just for you. In this blog, you'll learn how to convert a “normal” key user custom field to an ABAP Managed Field. With that, you can do all the changes supported by ABAP Managed Fields.

You can refer to this blog for an introduction into ABAP Managed Fields.

Let's say that you created a key user custom field of type “Code List”. You want to change the code list values directly in the production system instead of maintaining them in the development system and then transporting them over to the production system. You can refer to this blog for a comprehensive overview of custom field types providing a value list.
There may also be other reasons why you want to transform a key user custom field to an ABAP Managed field. Some of these reasons could be that:

  • you want to change the case sensitivity flag of the domain of your key user custom field from case sensitive to not case sensitive
  • you want to have a specific conversion routine within the domain of your key user custom field 
  • you want to specify a certain DDIC search help or check table

Please note that this blog  exclusively addresses SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA On-Premise and doesn’t address SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, as the feature of ABAP Managed Fields is not available in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

 

Convert a key user custom field to an ABAP Managed Field

Let’s assume you created, published and transported a key user custom field ZZ1_AssignedDepartment of type "Code List" of length 11 on the Sales Order business object (business context is SD_SALESDOC) where the code list consists out of three values (“Department1”, “Department2”, “Department3”).

Key user custom field creation for custom field ZZ1_AssignedDepartment

Several weeks after using the field in the production system, you may find that you want to change the code list values directly in the production system. This approach avoids maintaining these values in the development system and transporting them to the production system.

A more complicated approach to changing the code list values directly in the production system is to create a custom business object and use it in a new key user custom field of type “Association to Business Object”, since the data of custom business objects can be entered directly in the production system. You can transport the custom field along with all other development objects needed. As a next step, you create a report and class(es) in order to let you migrate the data from the old custom field to the new one.
The development effort for such a migration is significant, and it's even worse if you've already used the exposed old custom field in an integration scenario. You'd have to change everything there, too, as the name of the custom field changes.

Starting from S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2023 and On-Premise 2023, there is a new functionality that lets you convert the already existing key user custom field of type "Code List" to an ABAP Managed Field.
When you do this for a "Code List" field, the generated code value table, the code description table, the value help view, the value help description view, the data element, the domain, and the persistence include append all are preserved, but detached from the custom field itself. They're now under your manual control. This way, the code list values and descriptions are no longer part of the transport objects belonging to the custom field.
To be able to maintain the code values and code description values, there are multiple options:

  • create a maintenance view and maintenance dialog on top of the two persistence tables 
  • create a RAP application on top of these two persistence tables

In this blog, we'll show you the first option. Let's say you created a custom field ZZ1_AssignedDepartment. To convert this custom field to an ABAP Managed Field, and to make sure that the value help values can subsequently be maintained in the production system, follow this blog.

1. Open field ZZ1_AssignedDepartment in transaction SCFD_FIELDVIEWER

Open transaction SCFD_FIELDVIEWER in the system and client where you created the key user custom field ZZ1_AssignedDepartment. You'll see a list of all key user custom fields in that system. Double click the custom field ZZ1_AssignedDepartment.
When you go to the Enhancements tab on the field detail screen, you'll see the list of enhancements which have been generated for this particular key user custom field (see screenshot below). These enhancements all belong to this one custom field and can't be changed manually.

List of enhancements belonging to the custom field

2. Convert field ZZ1_AssignedDepartment to an ABAP Managed field

The next step is to click on the “Convert to ABAP Managed Field” button on the top left of the screen (see screenshot below). Make sure that the custom field you want to transform has been selected before on the left side of the screen.

Click on “Convert to ABAP Managed Fields” button

A popup will be shown asking you whether you “really want to convert the field to an ABAP managed field? The action is not reversible”. Click "Yes" to start the conversion process. As soon as the conversion has run, a respective success popup is shown.

Conversion success popup

Let's have a look at what happened behind the scenes during the conversion process:
Once again, have a look at the Enhancements tab of the custom field.

List of enhancements belonging to the custom field after the transformation

The list has become much shorter than before. The reason for that is that seven of the generated objects do now no longer exclusively belong to the custom field, but have been detached from the custom field and became independent development objects. These development objects are still used by the custom field, but can now be changed manually with the respective DDIC low-level tools, for example. These objects are:

      • Code Value Table: ZZ1_513D258A0759    
      • Code Description Table: ZZ1_EA4F9E9F7B2F     
      • CDS Code Value View: ZZ1_ASSIGNEDDEPARTMENT_V               
      • CDS Code Description View:  ZZ1_ASSIGNEDDEPARTMENT_W               
      • Data Element: ZZ1_ASSIGNEDDEPARTMENT               
      • Domain: ZZ1_ASSIGNEDDEPARTMENT
      • Persistence Include Append: ZZ1_VRTNU6KIWGDFIEIAVO2GXBFNTQ

With this transformation, the former custom field became an ABAP Managed Field as if it had been created from scratch as an ABAP Managed field using transaction SCFD_EUI. For this ABAP Managed Field, the same rules apply as for any other ABAP Managed field. The following two blogs dive deeper into ABAP Managed fields and address the specifics of them (especially regarding software logistics):

      • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/convert-manually-created-append-fields-to-real-key-user-custom-fields/ba-p/13967399
      • https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/key-user-custom-fields-in-s-4hana-cloud-private-edition-and-on-premise-dos/ba-p/14026871

There is one more aspect to consider in case you want to transform a CodeList custom field to an AMF field. The code values and the code description values are no longer part of the transport object of the respective field. They do now only exist locally in the respective system and must be maintained in each system individually (but note: this is exactly what we wanted to achieve).

3. Create a maintenance view and a maintenance dialog for the code value and the code description table

The next step is to create a maintenance view for the code value table and the code description table. On top of this maintenance view, a maintenance dialog should be created. You can learn how to do this in the following blog: https://community.sap.com/t5/application-development-and-automation-blog-posts/getting-started-with-abap-how-to-create-maintenance-view/ba-p/13533494

Follow these steps to, for example, create the maintenance view ZZ1_DEPMNT_MV.

4. Maintain the code and the code description values using the maintenance view

Using the maintenance view ZZ1_DEPMNT_MV, you can now create, maintain, and delete entries for the two tables  ZZ1_513D258A0759 and ZZ1_EA4F9E9F7B2F. You can do this by navigating to the maintenance view using SE11. Click on Contents (see screenshot below).  The old values that you've maintained using the custom fields tool are preserved.

Maintain code values and code description locally using a maintenance view

Please note that the descriptions are maintained in table ZZ1_EA4F9E9F7B2F using the login language as language so you don't have to enter the language manually.

With this, you are done. You successfully transformed the key user custom field to an ABAP Managed Field. As a consequence, you no longer have to maintain the value help values (codes and descriptions) in the development system and transport them over to the target system. Now, you can maintain the values directly in the local system itself.

Please note that using a maintenance view in order to maintain the value help values (codes and descriptions) is just one possibility out of many. You could, for example, also create a RAP application on top of the code and description tables in order to create and maintain the value help values.

Now, you are done! Congratulations!
With this, you’re now equipped to convert a key user custom field to an ABAP Managed Field.

Please note that for the following field types of custom fields, a conversion to an ABAP Managed field is not supported:

  • “Amount with currency”
  • “Quantity with unit”
  • “Code List based on CDS View”
  • “Association to Business Object”

If you try to convert a field with this field type, you'll get an error popup telling you that the conversion for type [field type] is not supported.

Please note that this blog has been elaborated by a team of experts. I want to thank Yasmina van Rooij (YasminavanRooij), Karsten Schaser (Karsten_Schaser) and Christian Fuhlbruegge (ChristianFuhlbruegge) for their extremely helpful contributions.

Feedback, Comments, or Questions

You’re cordially invited to provide feedback, comments, or questions in the comments section below. Please follow our profiles to get updates when we publish more posts on these topics.
Feel invited to post and answer questions here (https://answers.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26) and read other posts on the topic (https://blogs.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26/).

entry.title: SAP Master Data Integration (MDI) – Bank and Cost Center Replication from S/4HANA
entry.content:
In continuation of my previous blogs on MDI Architecture and Deployment and Business Partner Replication, this post focuses on Bank and Cost Center replication from an SAP S/4HANA system to SAP Master Data Integration (MDI).

Master Data objects like Banks and Cost Centers are foundational across multiple systems. Enabling seamless replication to MDI ensures a harmonized master data landscape, supporting a clean core and extensible architecture.

Common Configuration Steps

Before configuring the replication-specific models, there are common prerequisites applicable to both Bank and Cost Center integration. These ensure secured, authenticated communication and connectivity between S/4HANA and MDI.

1. OAuth 2.0 Client Configuration

Use transaction OA2C_CONFIG to configure your OAuth 2.0 client. This allows S/4HANA to authenticate securely with the SAP MDI service.

2. Create RFC Destination

Use transaction SM59 to create a destination pointing to MDI, essential for connectivity.

3. Configure MDI Destination

Use transaction S_SAL_71000052 to access view V_MDI_DEST_CONF and configure your destination here.

4. BGRFC Configuration

Set up Inbound BGRFC Destinations using SBGRFCCONF. This ensures reliable communication for asynchronous data transfers.

5. Extract AIF Content

Run /AIF/CONTENT_EXTRACT with SAP_COM_0659 to extract the content needed for integration scenarios.

6. Publish OData V4 Services

Use /IWFND/V4_ADMIN to publish OData V4 service groups if not already done.

7. Create Technical User

Use SU01 to create a user that will be used for background processing and secure calls.

8. Assign Required Role

Clone the role SAP_CA_DRF_MDO using PFCG and assign it to the technical user created above.

9. Configure SAP BTP Destination

Ensure the destination is correctly set in the SAP BTP Cockpit pointing to your S/4HANA On-Prem system.

Cost Center Replication Setup

A. Push Model Configuration

Configure a push model to automatically send data to MDI when a Cost Center is created or changed.

B. Pull Model Testing

To validate the integration, use a REST client such as Postman to pull data from MDI after the Push model replicates it.

Sample replicated Cost Center data can be verified in Postman once changes are triggered from S/4HANA.

C. Output Test

Bank Replication Setup

A. Push Model Configuration

Similar to Cost Center, set up a Push Model for Banks to send data changes automatically to MDI.

B. Pull Model Testing

Again, Postman can be used as a mock target system to verify the successful pull of replicated bank data from MDI.

C. Output Test

Summary

With this setup, you’ve now enabled real-time or near-real-time replication of Bank and Cost Center data from S/4HANA to SAP MDI, supporting both Push and Pull models. This ensures data consistency across systems and promotes a modular, scalable enterprise data architecture.

Please note the Blog is to connect S/4HANA on-prem/Private Cloud system to MDI, there can be more scenario where the MDI would be then connected to other systems. For such scenarios, configuration is required in Master Data Orchestration or Business Data Orchestration.
